qas.question: What did John Quincy Adams say about Georgia?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Seminole<b5_0/> Indians based in East Florida began raiding <b4_0>Georgia<b4_0/> settlements<a0_0/>, and offering havens for <a1_0><b6_0>runaway slaves<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The United States Army led increasingly frequent incursions into Spanish territory, including the 1817–1818 campaign against the Seminole Indians by Andrew Jackson that became known as the <a2_0>First Seminole War<a2_0/>. The United States now effectively controlled East Florida. Control was necessary according to Secretary of State <b7_0>John Quincy Adams<b7_0/> because Fl<a3_0>orida <b8_0>had become "a derelict open to the occupancy of every enemy<b8_0/>, civilized or savage<a3_0/>, of the United States, and serving no other earthly purpose than as a post of annoyance to them.".
